chosen.content: Why are so many stores closed on Sundays? Is it a religious reason?

No.  The USA was founded by a Puritan group of Protestants, but it didn’t adopt the religion of the Puritans until much later, and it was always a secular state.  The Puritans observed the Sabbath on Sunday, and the Puritans only had a small influence in the early history of the USA.  It’s difficult to trace the origins of closing stores on Sunday, but one early and short-lived attempt at forcing the Sabbath on people in the 1800s was motivated by the Protestant ideal that people should spend Sunday focusing on spiritual activities.  By the mid-1800s, when the Sunday closing law was made, there was not a lot of pressure from that standpoint, but the church had begun to advocate for Sunday closing laws as a way of counteracting the negative effects of industrialization on the day of rest.  Even after that shift, closing stores on Sunday was not always possible, since the religious Sunday was not always chosen for observance.  And as industrialization accelerated and mechanization made it possible to operate stores on Sunday, the law was not enforced as much as people liked.  The day of rest was also being violated by stores that stayed open all day on Sunday, so closing stores on Sundays became an effort to protect the Sabbath for all citizens.

chosen.content: What is macular degeneration?

Well, macular degeneration is a common condition where the cells in the center of the retina (called the macula) lose their ability to receive light.  This loss of visual function, usually due to damage to the blood vessels that supply the retina, leads to blindness in the affected eye(s).  The condition is very common in people over the age of 60.  It’s not treatable and cannot be reversed.
Do you know what damages the blood vessels that supply the retina?

Yes, it’s caused by the build up of toxic deposits (called drusen) in the eye, similar to the build up of calcium deposits in your arteries that can lead to hardening of the arteries.  The leading causes of this build up of deposits are smoking, high cholesterol levels, high blood pressure, and diabetes.
Can an ophthalmologist see the drusen?
Yes, it’s possible for an ophthalmologist to see them with an ophthalmoscope, or a slit lamp.  They also can use a test called fluorescein angiography to look at the blood flow through the retina.
And can the drusen be removed?

Not at the current time.  Even the fluorescein angiography can’t reliably show where the drusen are located.  The way this disease usually progresses is that first the blood flow slows down in the center of the retina.  In the early stages of the disease, a very low dose of a drug called a vasodilator (like Diamox) can improve the blood flow, but later this can’t be done.  The macular degeneration progresses and eventually the retina becomes disconnected from the central area of the brain that controls vision.
Is testing being done to find a cure for macular degeneration?

Yes, there’s a very large effort to find better methods of treating macular degeneration and to develop a cure, such as via gene therapy.  There’s also research to find the causes and improve treatments for the conditions that lead to the build up of drusen.  One major focus of this research is to understand how to prevent damage to the blood vessels that supply the retina in the first place.  This involves studying factors like oxidative stress, inflammation, and vascular damage.

If you were floating in space, and grabbed one end of it and held it, then the other end would stretch to the ground, into the ground and back out again.  If you stood on the ground, you could then pull it and have it lift you up into the air.  The question is, could the Earth rotate under the “wormhole” while the person holding it was “in the air”?
